BC-SCI-WATCH-NYT 
SCIENCE NOTES AND NEWS 

   (The Science Times)  
 By HENRY FOUNTAIN    
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service    

   When Asteroids Grow Up

   It is a fine line, sometimes, between fame and obscurity. Take
the case of the celestial object known as 1999 UX18. One day it's
an asteroid, just another bit player meandering around the solar
system. The next day it's a star.

   Or rather, a moon. Astronomers at the University of Arizona and
the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory have determined that the
small object, thought to be an asteroid when it was discovered near
Jupiter last year, is in fact an outer satellite of the planet.

   The object was one of many observed by the University of
Arizona's Spacewatch program, which uses a 36-inch telescope to
look for comets and asteroids. It was cataloged by the
Smithsonian's Minor Planet Center and pretty much forgotten.

   But a staff member of the center, testing new software last
month, thought he came across another observation of the object in
the Spacewatch data. He tried to come up with a solar orbit for the
object that would account for the various observations. When he
could not, it dawned on him that perhaps he was wrongly assuming
that the object was orbiting the Sun. Perhaps it was actually
orbiting Jupiter.

   That turned out to be the case, although its orbit, like those
of the other outer satellites, is highly irregular and millions of
miles from the planet. And the object is so small _ about three
miles in diameter, perhaps _ that it is difficult to see. But the
astronomers hope to make another set of observations to confirm
their finding. And if it is confirmed as a moon, 1999 UX18 will
eventually get a name worthy of its billing.

   Undoing Fish Evolution

   Astyanax mexicanus, a fish found in Mexico, is an unusual
creature. It exists in two forms: sightless cave dwellers that have
degenerate orbs in place of eyes, and those that live in surface
streams and have normal eyes. The two are thought to have diverged
from a common ancestor within the past million years.

   Now, scientists at the University of Maryland have uncovered
clues to how they evolved differently. They report in the journal
Science that the eye lens plays a critical role in the development
(or degeneration) of the eye.

   In the cave-dwelling variety, eyes begin to develop in the
embryo, but the lens quickly degenerates and other eye tissues like
the cornea, retina and pupil develop in only rudimentary form. But
when the researchers implanted lens tissue from the sighted variety
into a cave-dweller embryo, a large eye with a distinct cornea,
pupil and iris developed. It is as if the researchers were able to
undo a million years of evolution in one fell swoop.

   The researchers are conducting further experiments to determine
exactly how the lens tissue sets off eye development. The work may
eventually help in understanding the genetic factors behind certain
forms of sight loss in humans.

   Those Talkative Beans

   It's hard to find something nice to say about lima beans, other
than that they are easy to spear with a fork. But researchers in
Japan have uncovered a reason the vegetable may be worthy of new
respect. Limas, it turns out, are good communicators.

   Like some other types of plants, a lima can let its neighbors
know when it has been attacked by a pest such as a spider mite. The
action of the mite munching on the plant releases volatile
compounds that are carried through the air to neighboring lima
plants, which then prepare chemical defenses against infestation.

   While it had been known that limas could do this, the exact
mechanism had remained unclear. The Japanese researchers, reporting
in Nature, discovered that the volatile compounds activate five
defense genes in an uninfested plant.

   What's more, the plants can differentiate between a mite
infestation and physical damage that might be caused, say, by being
stepped on. The compounds released by a damaged plant are ignored
by its neighbors.
